Your going into there home. You need to treat it as your a guest all the ti=
me not like your there to piss them off.Because you will get stuff you do n=
ot like.For example We did n investigation with my old group.We did not do =
a closing prayer and I got in deep shit with my fam. Because they followed =
me home.Until I made it right.

--- On Sat, 12/13/08, Zack Widup <w9sz@prai=
rienet.org> wrote:

I was on a recent investigati=
on where we were told getting angry and into 
fights seemed to get the best=
 response from whatever was there. We just 
couldn't bring ourselves to do =
that, though. We couldn't bring ourselves 
to provoke or challenge anything=
, either. However, asking it politely to 
do something - anything - did get=
 a response once.

Zack

On Sat, 13 Dec 2008, Cheri Esperon wrote:

> It de=
pends on what is going on. Since the focus on the investigation is
> more t=
han just gathering EVPs sometimes there needs to be more
> chatter. Actual =
investigations can take hours and sometimes several
> visits, so what you s=
ee on a show is maybe 8-10 hours compressed into 45
> minutes. As far as th=
anking the spirits, again it depends on what is
> needed and the personalit=
y of the investigator.
>
> Researching at home is a lot different- at home =
you are in your comfort
> zone, I have a residual energy that walks down my=
 hallway, I have seen
> it a hundred times, and it never freaks me out. But=
 if I see something
> out on an investigation- in a strange location where =
I am out of my
> comfort zone, it will freak me out a little-- get the hear=
t racing. And
> I have been known to ask what the H-E double hockey sticks =
was that?
> Now I will run towards something- others instinctively start to=
 run
> away- again it depends the personality and experience of the
> inves=
tigator, lol and the vocabulary.
>
> In a team envvironment usually and in =
my opinion, hopefully, you have a
> variety of styles and personalities. I =
personally think that works
> better since you never know who might attract=
 a response.
>
